questionListItems.title: For PSLE written exams, should my child use 0.5 mm black or blue ink pens only?

answer.body:
Pupils are recommended to use a 0.5mm tip ballpoint pen for their PSLE written exams. Pupils have to write their answers clearly in black (recommended) or dark blue ballpoint pen and draw diagrams with a sharp 2B pencil. This reduces possible smudging and to ensure that the handwriting is clear.

You may visit the SEAB website at https://www.seab.gov.sg/home/examinations/psle for more information.

questionListItems.title:
When will parents receive the secondary school compilation booklet which contains the eligibility
criteria for all Secondary schools?

answer.body:
The hard-copy booklet will be given to all P6 pupils, right after their PSLE written examination in
October.

questionListItems.title: Why do CCA stand down for the P6 pupils in Term 3?

answer.body:
This is to allow the subject teachers to better prepare the pupils for their PSLE examination, taking into
consideration that Oral examination commences in early August.

• Pupils will report to school by 7.30 am in the hall or classrooms.
• Pupils will be having silent reading before the commencement of our PRe-Assembly Moments (PRAM)
at 7.25 am and the daily Flag Raising Ceremony at 7.30 am.
• Access to the school by foot is via the Front Gate and/or Back Gate.
• Vehicles are allowed to drive in through the Main Gate for parents to drop off the pupils at the Foyer
in the morning. Motorcycles are to stop near the staircase area where a staff will be on duty.
• Pupils will be considered late if they arrive in the Hall or classroom after 7.30 am.

questionListItems.title: What should I do if I need to visit the school?

answer.body:
Parent/guardians will have to fill in their details and obtain a Visitor’s Pass from the Security Guard
House before proceeding to the General Office for further assistance, which is subjected to changes in
the school security requirements.
• Kindly note that visitors are strictly NOT allowed to loiter in the school compound.

questionListItems.title: What are the After-School Care options available?

answer.body:
• Little Professors @ Westwood partners our school in providing school-based student care services to
our pupils. Parents may contact Little Professors at 8606 1170 or westwood@littleprofessors.com.sg for
any enquires during operating hours.
• Alternatively, parents may access this link to get details:
https://www.facebook.com/littleprofessorslearningcentre

questionListItems.title: Can I transfer my child to Westwood Primary School?

answer.body:
You can apply to transfer your child to a primary school nearer to your new residential address if your child is:

  • A Singapore Citizen (SC) or Permanent Resident (PR).

  • Currently in Primary 1 to 5.

Please visit the MOE website at https://www.moe.gov.sg/primary/transfers for more information. Every year, students can transfer schools in the months of June and December.


If you intend to transfer your child to Westwood Primary School in other months, please visit the school website at https://www.westwoodpri.moe.edu.sg/administration/waiting-list/ for more information.

questionListItems.title: Will there be a physical school tour for the P1 pupils on the first few days of school?

answer.body:
Yes, a school tour will be conducted during the P1 Induction Programme during the first few days of
school to help the P1 pupils familiarise with the school environment.

questionListItems.title: Do the children have to bring all their books and files on a daily basis?

answer.body:
• Pupils should pack their bags daily according to the lessons stated in their timetable.
• Form/subject teachers will also be collecting and storing some of the textbooks, workbooks, exercise
books and files in school to prevent students from carrying heavy bags to school every day.

questionListItems.title: What to pack for the first day of school?

answer.body:
• As we are conducting an induction programme for all pupils on the first few days of school, there will
not be any formal teaching lessons. Pupils are only required to bring their basic stationery, some pocket
money or packed food for recess, and dry, healthy snacks for snack break.
• Parents are advised to label all of your child’s personal items like his/her wallet, pencil case, water
bottle, lunch/snack pack, school bag and school shoes for easy identification. Do provide a clean
resealable bag or face mask container for keeping of your child’s face mask as well.

questionListItems.title: What is the class size and how are the classes allocated?

answer.body:
• For P1 and P2, each class will have 30 pupils. For P3 to P6, each class will have 40 pupils.
• P3 pupils will be re-allocated to different classes due to the change in class size. We will consider a
balanced number of the gender and social mixing as far as possible.
• P5 pupils will also be re-allocated to different classes due to subject-based banding, which is
conducted at the end of P4.

questionListItems.title: What is the teacher pupil ratio for each class?

answer.body:
• The Teacher to Pupil ratio for P1 and P2 classes is 1:30. • The Teacher to Pupil ratio for P3 to P6 classes
is 1:40.

questionListItems.title: How will children with Special Education Needs (SEN) be supported?

answer.body:
• Specialised personnel, provisions and programmes will be deployed to provide special needs support,
catering to the different levels and learning needs of our pupils.
• The Learning and Behavioural Support (LBS) provided by Allied Educators will provide individual or
small group interventions, as such skills training or in-class support.
• The Learning Support Programmes (LSP) is conducted for selected P1 and P2 pupils who need
additional help with the learning of English Language and Mathematics. This programme is held during
curriculum time daily, and in small groups of 8 to 10 pupils.
• The Reading Remediation Programme (RRP) is an additional literacy support programme for selected
P3 and P4 pupils with reading difficulties. This programme is conducted after-school.

questionListItems.title:
Are there exams for P1 and P2? If there are no exams, how do the teachers assess my child’s learning
progress?

answer.body:
There will be no examinations/weighted assessments for P1 and P2 pupils. The teachers will use non-
weighted assessments to support pupils’ learning, gauge their learning progress and address learning
gaps. They will also gather information about pupils’ learning through learning checkpoints such as class
discussions, in-class work, bite-sized tests, performance tasks and qualitative descriptors will be used to
report pupils’ progress in their report books.

questionListItems.title: What if I want to know about my child’s learning progress in school?

answer.body:
• We encourage parents to engage in regular conversations with their child about his/her learning
progress. Books and files will be returned periodically for parents to have a better idea of their child’s
learning progress in school. Please acknowledge and return the items promptly. If parents need further
clarifications, please do check in with the teachers.
• The Teacher-Parent-Pupil Conference will be held once a year in May, where parents will engage in a
conversation with their child’s Form teachers to learn more about his/her learning progress in school.
